content:
The country’s polls are good enough to justify the assumption that the fire-breathing conservative will win

ON OCTOBER 28th Brazil will head to the polls to elect its next president. Latin America’s largest democracy must choose between Fernando Haddad, the nominee of the Workers’ Party (PT), and Jair Bolsonaro, a right-wing populist. Mr Bolsonaro is currently ahead by 11 points, according to a sample-weighted average of the latest polls. Should there be any reason to doubt that he will win?

Some scepticism about the accuracy of Brazil’s polls is warranted. Surveys taken in the week leading up to the first round of Brazil’s election on October 7th showed that 35-40% of voters would vote for Mr Bolsonaro. Yet he won 46% of the valid votes cast, just short of the 50% required to win the presidency at the first shot.

How much faith should we put in Brazil’s polls? To find out The Economist has compared the accuracy of Brazilian election polls with those from around the world. We used a dataset compiled by Will Jennings and Chris Wlezien, both political scientists, covering some 300 elections held between 1942 and 2017 in 45 countries, including Brazil. We combined this with additional data on Brazilian elections provided to us by Ryan Lloyd, Mathieu Turgeon, also political scientists, and Neale El-Dash, a statistical consultant who runs a Brazilian polling aggregator .

Contrary to popular belief, election polling worldwide is fairly accurate. In 2016, for example, America’s much-maligned pollsters correctly predicted that Hillary Clinton, the Democratic candidate for president, would win the popular vote. They overestimated Ms Clinton’s lead over Donald Trump by just 1.1 percentage points.

Our analysis finds that Brazil’s polling does indeed underperform compared with the international average in both legislative elections and for the first round of presidential votes. Mr El-Dash thinks that the relatively poor accuracy of Brazilian polls can be partly explained by the fact that many are conducted in person, rather than by phone. It is difficult for pollsters to reach both rich voters in gated communities and poor ones living in crime-ridden favelas . Brazilians are last-minute decision-makers, too. So polls taken a week or so before election day will not capture the momentum candidates might have.

Brazil’s second-round polls, however, are much more accurate, according to our analysis. We find that in the four presidential elections held between 2002 and 2014, an average of the second-round polls taken the week before the election missed the final outcome by just 2.5 points. That is no worse than the global average. The reasons for the improved accuracy of Brazilian polls in the second round are unclear. Perhaps, faced with fewer candidates to choose from, voters are quicker to make up their minds. Short of divine intervention at the 11th hour, Mr Bolsonaro’s lead, which is now in double digits, looks unlikely to disappear.

Their findings support restrictions on lighting up within a few feet of other people. But they don't warrant more than that.
他们的观测结果支持了对在他人几尺之外吸烟的限制，但是除此之外，它们并不能证明更多。

Title: Brazil’s next president is likely to be Jair Bolsonaro

paperStatistics.title: Brazil’s next president is likely to be Jair Bolsonaro
paperStatistics.desc: The country’s polls are good enough to justify the assumption that the fire-breathing conservative will win
